title: Tourism booming in farming's place: Mike Yardley
text:
Tourism booming in farming's place: Mike Yardley MIKE YARDLEY Last updated 16:56, August 31 2015 DON SCOTT/FAIRFAX NZ 
Day one of filming on the Lord of the Rings set of Edoras at Sunday Island on the upper reaches of the Rangitata River in South Canterbury back in 2001. 
With dairy in the doldrums and farming regions like North Canterbury gripped by drought, thank God tourism is booming. 
Our surging tourism industry is set to become our biggest export earner, with annual visitor numbers hitting the 3 million milestone. 
The sector's lofty ambition is to double annual visitor spending from $20 billion to $41 billion by 2025. 
I'm just back home after tripping through South America, where I was constantly struck by the irrepressible marketing power of Middle Earth. It's the gift that keeps on giving. 
Whenever I mentioned I was from New Zealand, Peruvians, Chileans and Brazilians gushed effusively about our "beautiful country", instantly referencing The Hobbit . Cinematic scenery is New Zealand's greatest calling card. 
Underscoring tourism's buoyancy, Air New Zealand hoisted a record annual profit last week , as the national carrier gears up to spread its wings dramatically. In December, direct services commence to Buenos Aires (Argentina) and Houston (United States). 
The airline's unwavering strategy to hub all long-haul services out of Auckland doesn't wash well with strident parochial sentiments in Christchurch but it's a business model that underpins the carrier's world-leading performance. 
I was chatting to a charming couple from Texas who are ecstatic about non-stop services to New Zealand from the Lone Star State. They're planning to trip down here next year, after having their last holiday abruptly curtailed by the February 2011 quake. 
They were in Akaroa when the earth convulsed – and evacuated by the US embassy. 
As we discussed Canterbury's visitor offerings, we agreed the diversity of our region's signature visitor draws is truly world-class, notwithstanding the slow but steady reassemblage of Christchurch. Ad Feedback 
From the healing haven of Hanmer and unplugged wildlife encounters of Kaikoura to the dark sky delights of Mackenzie and French flair of Akaroa, it's an enviable visitor proposition, all accessible within a three hour radius of the gateway city. 
Friday's launch of the Canterbury Economic Development Strategy highlights how pivotal tourism is to the region's long-term, post-rebuild economic prosperity. 
At the helm, Dame Margaret Bazley – the public sector's sharpest Swiss army knife. It's pleasing to see the development and implemention of a cohesive regional visitor strategy will be led by Kaikoura Mayor Winston Gray, illustrating how lucrative the satellite districts are to Canterbuy's tourism crown. 
Choreographed to chime in with the launch, Christchurch Airport confirmed that China Southern, the world's third largest airline, will operate a year-round, long-haul service between Christchurch and Guangzhou, from December. It's a major coup for the airport, seemingly clinched by the Lianne Dalziel-led delegation to China earlier this year. - Stuff
